Award.AwardTitle: Scalable Manufacturing of Nanostructured Bioassemblies for Low-Cost Portable Biosensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a growing demand for developing manufacturing processes that can reliably and reproducibly generate nanostructured materials with functional bioactive properties at low cost and in large quantities. These technologies are needed in a wide range of applications, especially in medical diagnostics and in environmental and food monitoring. Examples include responsive materials for wearable biosensing devices, flexible bioelectronics, functional contact lenses, smart screens and intelligent packaging. For example, bioactive nanostructures that have the appropriate detection sensitivity and selectivity are particularly important for the development of low cost devices for home and point-of-care diagnosis. This research will develop a process for large scale manufacturing of functional bioactive nanostructures on flexible and inexpensive substrates such as paper and plastic, using three-dimensional (3D) printing. This award will enable the development of a new class of biosensing devices that are easy to use, portable and inexpensive. Research outcomes will be disseminated through journals and conference presentations, including hands-on demonstrations of the sensing capabilities of the nanomanufactured devices, curriculum enhancement and professional development workshops for high school teachers, collaboration with industry, and providing entrepreneurial training for students.

This project will develop scalable fabrication methods for nanobioactive materials with defined optical and electronic properties and biological functionality. The overall goal is to gain fundamental understanding of the formation mechanism of hybrid bioactive nanostructures by printing and to use this knowledge to develop scalable production methods for low cost diagnostic applications. The research team will focus on the engineering design of eco-friendly printing inks of characteristic viscosity and composition that maintain functional nanoscale properties and bioactivity. These nanostructures will integrate biorecognition, signal amplification and detection capabilities and will function as all-in-one biosensing devices. Fabrication steps and detection schemes will be developed to facilitate automatic printing of the entire sensing unit and enable reagentless operation. The approach can be expanded to the synthesis of other hybrid nanostructures and devices with tailored functionality. The method will open the way for the in situ assembly of hybrid bioactive nanostructures using a low cost, versatile and controllable manufacturing process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on developing a process for the large scale manufacturing of functional bioactive nanostructures on flexible and inexpensive substrates. The overall goal was to gain fundamental understanding of the formation mechanism of bioactive nanostructures by printing and to use this knowledge to develop scalable production of low cost biosensors, with potential applications in the clinical, food and environmental fields. These nanostructures integrate biorecognition, signal amplification and detection capabilities and function as all-in-one devices. Fabrication steps and sensing mechanisms are developed to facilitate printing of the entire sensing unit and enable reagentless operation. The method opens up new ways for the in situ assembly and manufacturing of hybrid nanostructures using a low cost and versatile process. The developed biosensors are easy-to-use, portable and inexpensive. The project included activities to develop and implement new educational materials focusing on nanofabrication and device manufacturing and activities to provide entrepreneurial training for students. Active recruitment and opportunities for research and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students, primarily from underrepresented minority groups and females have been actively pursued.

Scalable fabrication of bioactive nanostructures is essential for the construction of inexpensive, lightweight, disposable, flexible and wearable devices. A requirement for the manufacturing of nanodevices is the ability to mass produce and integrate the nanocomponents at a low cost and with high reproducibility. This research developed optically responsive nanostructures in printable formulations and established the design characteristics needed to maintain uniformity, stability, reactivity and the physicochemical characteristics of these materials for sensing. It identified functional relationships between the material properties, ink composition, viscosity, curing conditions and the functioning of the resulting nano-enabled devices. These fundamental studies lead to the development of robust chemical and biological sensors prepared by 3D and 2D printing. The knowledge generated can be used broadly to fabricate biosensors for large scale monitoring in fields such as environment, medical, security, food quality control and agriculture. Several examples of such prototypes for detection of heavy metals, hypoxanthine, ethanol, lactate, and a wearable sensor for monitoring UV exposure have been demonstrated in this project.

The project provided ample opportunities for graduate and undergraduate research, as well as educational activities impacting students from different majors, in chemistry, biomolecular science, chemical and mechanical engineering. Students were exposed to interdisciplinary training at the interface of material science with chemistry and device engineering. They used electrochemical, spectroscopic, microscopic and biochemical methods to characterize nanostructures, measure material properties, assess bioactivity, develop printing compositions, fabricate and perform analytical testing of printed biosensors. In addition students received training in entrepreneurship and have participated in local businesses competitions receiving awards for their innovations. These included prototypes for low cost sensing of heavy metal ion exposure and a chemical sensor for measuring corrosion. A total of 6 graduate students (3 female), and 10 undergraduates (6 female) have participated in this project. Two graduate students successfully defended their PhD thesis under this project and have secured postdoctoral or industry positions. Research findings have been disseminated broadly nationally and internationally, through publications in materials, analytical chemistry and biosensing journals, lectures and conference presentations at national and international meetings. Results have been disseminated in 11 peer reviewed publications in mainstream journals, 3 book chapters, and presented in over 30 presentations at local, national and international meetings with undergraduate and graduate students co-authors.
